content.text: To establish a comprehensive framework for the lawful, fair, and transparent processing of personal data of students, parents, and staff, ensuring compliance with Indonesian Law No. 27 of 2022 (PDP Law) and international best practices, and to define procedures for secure records management.
All data processing activities must adhere to the following principles:

items.title: Lawfulness, Fairness, and Transparency
points: Data is processed based on explicit consent or other legal grounds. Individuals are informed about how their data is used.

items.title: Purpose Limitation
points: Data is collected for specified, explicit, and legitimate purposes and not further processed in a manner that is incompatible with those purposes.

items.title: Data Minimization
points: Only personal data that is adequate, relevant, and limited to what is necessary for the purpose is collected.

items.title: Accuracy
points: Personal data must be accurate and, where necessary, kept up to date.

items.title: Storage Limitation
points: Data is kept in a form which permits identification of data subjects for no longer than is necessary for the purposes for which the personal data are processed.

items.title: Integrity and Confidentiality
points: Data is processed in a manner that ensures appropriate security, including protection against unauthorized or unlawful processing and against accidental loss, destruction, or damage.

content.text: Students, parents, and staff (data subjects) have the right to:

items: Right to Access: Request and receive a copy of their personal data.
Right to Rectification: Request correction of inaccurate or incomplete data.
Right to Erasure ('Right to be Forgotten'): Request the deletion of their data under certain conditions.
Right to Restrict Processing: Request the limitation of how their data is used.
Right to Withdraw Consent: Withdraw consent at any time for data processing based on consent.

content.text: All requests from data subjects must be processed within the timeframes stipulated by the PDP Law. A formal 'Data Subject Access Request' (DSAR) form should be used.
When a parent or staff member asks to see their data, the school must respond professionally and legally.

items: Verification: Verify the identity of the requester (e.g., check ID).
Scope: Clarify exactly what data is being requested.
Collection: Gather data from SIS, emails, and physical files.
Redaction: Remove information about *other* people (third parties) from the documents.
Delivery: Provide the data securely within 30 days.

content.text: Systematic control of student and staff records from creation to disposal is mandatory.
In the event of a suspected or confirmed data breach, the school must follow a clear incident response plan.

content.title: Incident Response Steps
content.purpose: To contain, assess, and remediate any data breach incident promptly.

steps.title: Containment
steps.desc: Immediately take steps to secure systems and prevent further data loss. Isolate affected systems if necessary.

steps.title: Assessment
steps.desc: Assess the scope and impact of the breach. Identify what data was compromised and who was affected.

steps.title: Notification
steps.desc: Notify the affected data subjects and the relevant authorities within the legally required timeframe (e.g., 3x24 hours).

steps.title: Review & Remediate
steps.desc: Conduct a post-incident review to understand the root cause and implement measures to prevent recurrence.

content.text: Technical controls are useless if staff are not aware of risks. Human error is the leading cause of data breaches.

items: Induction: All new staff must complete Data Protection training within their first week.
Annual Refresher: Mandatory update training for all staff every academic year.
Phishing Simulations: IT department conducts periodic fake phishing tests to raise awareness.
